column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0051] Advantages for the fabrication of a unitary structure of each insert 324, 424 include robustness and improved cost.
#Text=The labor for attaching each attachment portions 470 is eliminated by forming the attachment portions 370, 470 and the insert 324, 424 simultaneously.
#Text=The inserts 324, 424 may be more robust since they are not depending on an intermediate material for attaching.

#Text=And since there is not a secondary process involving heat treatment for attaching each attachment portions 370, 470 to each insert 324, 424, concerns regarding the development of hard spots in the wear surfaces of each insert 324, 424 are eliminated.

#Text=That is, if attachment portions are welded to an insert on the inner side, the opposing surface portion of the outer side may experience an undesirable change in properties, such as hardening, that may affect the performance of a rotor in operation.

#Text=FIG. 22, as contrasted with FIG. 7, illustrates that the pattern of the attachment portions of opposing inserts could be configured to effect an offset of the opposing attachment portions (as opposed to the axial alignment of the attachment portions 70 of FIG. 7) to permit the rotor to be axilly thinner (dimension TR), thereby reducing mass and therefore weight if so desired in a given brake application.

#Text=The offset may be accomplished by, for example, circumferentially rotating all inserts on the first brake pad wear surface 100 relative to the second brake pad wear surface 102 about the axis of the rotor, or by rearranging the attachment portions on opposing inserts to accomplish an alternating pattern, such as illustrated in FIG. 22.
#Text=[0052] Since a brake rotor is a rotating mass, placement of each attachment portion 70 requires fixturing to ensure accurate placement and symmetry for producing a balanced rotor.
#Text=A fixture for introducing each attachment portions 70 to the inserts 24 can be configured for manual, semi-automated or fully automated positioning and attaching.
#Text=Equal sizing and spacing of each insert 24 when surrounded by core material 106 is also important for meeting rotational mass balance requirements.
#Text=FIG. 3 illustrates inserts 24a, 24b and 24c arranged to provide a balanced brake rotor assembly.

#Text=Slight differences in part size and shape effecting weight may result in rotational imbalance detrimental to brake rotor performance, therefore it is important to maintain tight control of each individual each insert 24 and corresponding tooling details for equal arrangement in the casting mold.
#Text=Methods for producing repeatable, equally sized components are well known to one skilled in the art.
#Text=An exemplary method is by die stamping; however other processes such as laser cutting, water jet cutting, casting and the like can be used.
#Text=Positioning and spacing of each insert 24 is controlled by matching features in a mold cavity.
#Text=FIG. 10 shows a mold insert for an exemplary rotor configuration of three equally sized segments of each insert 24.
#Text=Other embodiments could employ single or multiple segments of each insert 24 to accomplish adequate configurations for the rotor friction wear surface.
#Text=[0053] An exemplary casting process for the brake rotor is permanent mold using a tool made in two steel halves with steel cores.
#Text=It would be well known to one skilled in the art that this process produces a dense casting of core material 106 with desirable mechanical properties compared to typical sand castings.

#Text=The steel mold halves and core details provide chilling adequate for enhancing the required mechanical properties, quality surface finishes, uniformity of shape and relatively close dimensional tolerance for reducing costly post-machining.
#Text=Permanent mold tooling also provides advantages for the high-production quantities demanded for automotive.
#Text=However, casting processes such as green sand molding could also be used.

#Text=[0054] In an exemplary embodiment of a method of forming a rotor 20, three segments of each insert are placed into the mold cavity of a previously described permanent mold, arranged as shown in FIG. 10 on each half of the tool, with attachment portions directed outward from the cavity surfaces.
#Text=Referring to FIG. 10, each insert is secured in place using a magnet or multiple magnets 500 arranged flush to a cavity surface 502.
#Text=An exemplary embodiment would use multiple magnets 500 in a pattern conforming to the arcuate shape of each insert.
#Text=The magnets 500 may of sufficient strength to hold the inserts in position throughout the casting process.
#Text=The magnets 500 may also be capable of maintaining permeability properties to withstand the high temperatures of the casting process.
#Text=High temperature permanent magnets made from materials such as samarium cobalt (SmCo) are suited for the application.
#Text=SmCo magnets maintain their strength when subjected to temperatures up to 550.degree.
#Text=C. (1022.degree.
#Text=F.).
#Text=The holding strength of the magnets 500 may also must be sufficient to penetrate multiple layers of refractory sprayed onto mold cavity surfaces 502 between cycles during the casting process.
#Text=Refractory build-up may become thick enough that occasional desired removal in the magnets 500 locations in order to maintain sufficient holding strength.
#Text=Other mechanical means for holding each insert in position could be used.
#Text=For example, tapered pins could extend from mold cavity surface 502 for pressing into corresponding holes in each insert 24.

#Text=The interference between pins and each insert 24 would be such for positively holding parts in place during the casting process without hindering removal of the finished casting from mold cavity.

#Text=[0055] FIGS. 20 and 21 illustrate an insert 24 which may be formed in any of the methods described herein, including a fastener, such as at least one screw or bolt 510 that could be affixed to or designed to pass thru each insert 24 into a mold cavity surface, such as the surface 502 and secured in place with mating nuts to hold the inserts 24 in position during casting.
#Text=With the opening of the mold, the securing nuts would be removed and the cast part ejected.
#Text=It would be necessary to remove each holding screw or bolt 510 flush to or below the exposed functional wear surface of each insert 24 during subsequent finish machining operations.
#Text=Such a process would likely be labor intensive and cumbersome when compared to the exemplary magnet holding method described herein.
#Text=Another holding method could be to use an adhesive applied to the outer surface 62 of each insert 24 to be in contact with mold cavity surface 502.
#Text=For example, a double-backed very high bond type adhesive with a peel-off release liner could be used.
#Text=Such an application would require the materials involved to be capable of withstanding the high temperatures of mold cavity contact surface 502 from continuous processing.
#Text=The strength of the adhesive would be configured for positively holding parts in place during the casting process without hindering removal of the finished casting from mold cavity.
